subject: Re: [junit] Test genes, test infected rates, and test-resistant managers
msgSnippet: ... I had plans to start a book on teaching OOP entirely through tests and TDD, but then I started to suffer some serious burnout and I have put that plan to
messageBody:
Jeremy D. Frens wrote:

> The problem now is a missing step in Joe's "algorithm". I'd add a step:
>
> 3.5. If enough teach it, teaching materials get produced.
>
> While this step is implicit in steps 4 and 5, I think *right now* it's
> the sticking point in the process, and so I'm going to make the step
> explicit.
>
> To my knowledge, no Java or C++ introductory textbooks describe or use
> JUnit. There are some excellent books on JUnit and TDD, but they're
> written for reasonably experienced programmers. We need materials for
> the beginning programmer. My CS 1 lab manual (which uses JUnit
> everywhere, all the time) is currently just for private use; I am
> planning to get it published somehow, somewhere. I hope to do the same
> to my PL materials.

I had plans to start a book on teaching OOP entirely through tests and
TDD, but then I started to suffer some serious burnout and I have put
that plan to the side for now. I strongly believe such a book would be
valuable, either as a fieldguide for teachers of all kinds, from
consultants and mentors to university instructors. I had hoped to have
such a thing out in 2008, but I don't know whether that will happen.

Take care.
